text:

author: Native Tube

text:
I've got t say, all these people say its corny, but man this was a revolution to technology. All that cool stuff we have today was just a fantasy in 1984. You have got to understand, this is before we had all this technological mumbo jumbo. In the year 1984, this was practically IMPOSSIBLE. A computer that could generate text on a screen, one that could generate pictures and documents to work on, let alone let it speak. The computer you have in your household today, no matter if it was a Mac/Pc/other was all based on this specific model. It is what gives us the miracle of computing today. And I don't know how we would be today if we did not have this first step in home computers.
Rest In Peace Steve Jobs. You changed the world.﻿

text:
+CORE Group To be honest, I get pissed off every time I hear about Jobs being a Computer God from the 80s and how Macintosh was the Birth of personal Computing. Jobs and his Computers were the laughing stock of the 80s. Nobody used them because they were Way To expensive, Lack of Software library and compatible hardware (that was affordable), No industrial Application, and most importantly, no freedom of writing and marketing your own software compatible with them. It was basically an Fuck you to Computing standards that most people refused to jump on the Bandwagon for. For example, you couldnt use the Hayes Smartmodem at all with the Apple, which wouldnt allow you to connect with BBSes. You had to use the piece of Shit AppleTalk that could only connect to their own network. 



The real computers that defined the 80s were the IBM PC, Commodore 64 and Amiga, DEC VAX and the Z80 computers. These Apple Morons don't know anything about that and It pisses me off that this piece of shit "Visionary" is getting the credit for what these Real Engineers did...﻿
author: Gholam Ahangari

text:
+Gholam Ahangari I believe he is a visionary in some respect. Just not really in the computer field. But definitely in the media player and cell phone markets.

I'm sure he isn't some computer god, because his computers now still aren't so great for how much you dish out for them. My friends 2000+ dollar Mac desktop sucks compared to my 1000+ dollar HP. And my 600 dollar HP laptop is a hell of a lot better (in my opinion) than my sisters 1000+ dollar macbook pro. And I'll guarantee both of my HP's will last longer. And work better for longer.

But you do have to admit, he did change cell phones forever with the iPhone. It takes HTC, Samsung, and Windows just to compete with the iPhone line. Also, something I did just realize is that even if his computers weren't top of the line revolutionary, his Lisa computer way back when started a competition that turned into a multi trillion dollar market. I would imagine every little bit counted back then right? ﻿
author: Brad Doan

text:
I think his Contributions to smartphone is what saved his legacy more than anything. He isnt an engineer, so I as an engineer can't give him the credit of building the damn thing. I give that to the programmers and hardware engineers who have to live up to his standards. But he may have came up with the ideas of improving the blackberry and newton and he came out with the Iphone. 

To this day, I cannot think of one person who cared, much less used, the Lisa Computer back in the 80s. The True father of the PC revolution was the IBM PC. Thats why the its called the PC revolution and the computers we have today are built on its Architecture. Here is the thing you have to understand regarding computers in the 80s. Back then, computers had very limited functions and you had to get software to operate them. Software was bought from a store or written by yourself or friends. Apple was against people writing their own software and they had a ridiculous certification program to allow people to program, let alone market software for their computers. And they usually cost much more, in addition to the extreme cost of the Computers themselves. Thats why Apple was such a failure in the 80s. Software was limited and expensive. 

In regards to the Lisa, the Lisa was built on the Motorolla 68000 platform and the only thing unique about it was how it wasted its potential. The 68000 used Flat-line memory to operate, meaning that unlike the 8086, there was no paging requirements and it could have run 10 times as fast as the 8086 of the IBM. But because they had a Document Centric OS, they had to constantly save and load the data in the Registers than just running it through making it much slower in the end. Programming the LISA was also a pain in the ass for that reason. Most 80s computer geeks like myself consider the true Revolutionary of the GUI comptuer to be the Commodore Amiga (which was also built on the 68000 but was much more utilizing of its potential). ﻿

However, thinks will improve vastly with 32gb ram, ssd hdds and a second xeon cpu. and two 4 GPUs (hd4870 x2) in crossfire and a 2000 watt psu and overclocking with watercooling. With such a setup, this plastic computer would melt in liquid form immediately from the heat. Only the old crt screen would remain.  If I was able to travel back them and presented my insanely heavy 2 xeon 32gb ram  rig, Job would gave me the company to play crysis, Watch Dogs and GTA 5 on my pc and put this small computer to its bug again.﻿
